This program is commencing in 2026.
The Master of Finance is a one to two-year postgraduate program delivered by Australia’s #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Developed in close consultation with the finance sector, this program exposes you to the latest thinking and research in finance.
With two entry points, students with a degree in a field other than finance can join the two-year program. Finance undergraduates who want to study advanced topics can choose the one-year option.
Put theory into practice
This course will help you develop a foundation of strong critical thinking and problem-solving skills. You'll have opportunities to apply your learnings in real-life settings, helping you feel confident in making financial decisions.
Hone your specialty
Our program allows you to tailor your expertise to your chosen career path. Choose from three specialisations: Funds Management, Corporate Finance & Investment Banking and Financial Technology, or hand-pick your own finance electives.
Grow strong industry connections
You'll be taught the latest theories and techniques by industry-leading academics and researchers, enhancing your educational and social skills. You'll also get access to the best networking functions, internships and mentors.
Add a competitive edge to your career
UNSW Finance graduates are highly sought-after in the workforce. The skills learned in this program are in-demand in many fields, particularly in the corporate setting.
The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications.
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:
Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:
Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted exemption for 12 UOC.
You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on your educational background and citizenship. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.
If you’re completing an Australian Year 12 qualification (e.g. NSW HSC or equivalent), you do not need to provide anything extra to prove your proficiency. Your qualification will be used as evidence of your English proficiency.
If you do need to provide evidence of your English proficiency, this will be indicated in your application. You can prove this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:
If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.
The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications. The entry requirements for the two pathways include:
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:
You’ll need the following:
Students who are not graduates of Australian or New Zealand universities
For students who studied at overseas universities, a credit average grade (65% or higher) is the normal academic requirement for Australian universities. You can calculate the equivalent using the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator. Details on assessment will be determined by your grading system so ensure this is attached to your transcript when you apply.

Note: Applicants from non-211 universities in China wishing to study Postgraduate Coursework in the UNSW Business School, must achieve a minimum overall average of 88 in their current university’s grading system. This is equivalent to an 85% Australian scaled average.
You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on whether you are from an English-speaking background or non-English speaking background. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.
If English is not your first language, you’ll need to provide proof of your English proficiency before you can be given an offer to study at UNSW. You can do this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:
UNSW is introducing a new academic calendar from 2028.
We are moving to a new flex-semester calendar. What does this mean for your studies?
This program provides the skills and experience you need to tailor your qualification to your career goals.
At UNSW, each university year has three terms and an optional summer study period. Full-time students can typically fit two or three courses in one term and one course in the summer term.
Below is a summary of what you will study in the Master of Finance:
Stage 1 | 48 units of credit (UOC)
Stage 2 | 48 units of credit (UOC)
For more information on the coursework, electives and specialisations please see the UNSW Online Handbook.
As a Master of Finance student, you’ll learn the theories and practical techniques specific to your career and professional growth. With internships, mentorships and networking opportunities, you can participate in hands-on learning both in and out of the classroom. Accelerate your career with Australia’s university ranked #1 for employment outcomes (QS World University Rankings, 2026).
UNSW Business School's Career Accelerator portfolio offers students exclusive access to a suite of for-credit, co-curricular and business experience opportunities to kick start your career.
You may be eligible for Associate membership with the Financial Services Institute of Australasia (FINSIA) upon completion of this degree.
Applications must be submitted through our Apply Online portal. We encourage you to submit your completed application as early as possible to ensure it will be processed in time for your preferred term. Some high-demand programs and Faculties with limited places may have an earlier application deadline or commencement date. Find out more.
For most international students, applications are submitted via our Apply Online service. We encourage you to submit your completed application as early as possible to ensure it will be processed in time for your preferred term.
Some high-demand programs with limited places, may have an earlier application deadline or may have an earlier commencement date. For details, visit the international admissions information page.
*Fees are subject to annual review (or when required) by the University and may vary accordingly.
Indicative fees are a guide only and have been calculated based on the typical enrolment patterns of students undertaking the program. The indicative fees listed here is an estimate for tuition only and excludes non-tuition fees and charges. The amount you pay will vary depending on the calendar year of enrolment, the courses you select and whether your study load is more or less than 1 Equivalent Full Time Student Load (48 units of credit (UOC) per year).
You should not rely on indicative fees as fee increases are assessed when required and may exceed the indicative figures listed here. Actual fees are calculated on enrolment. More information on fees can be found at the UNSW fees website.
*Fees are subject to annual review by the University and may increase annually, with the new fees effective from the start of each calendar year. The indicative fees listed here are based on an estimated average and are for tuition only, other fees and charges are not included. The amount you pay will vary depending on the calendar year to enrol, the courses you select and whether your study load is more or less than 1 Equivalent Full Time Student Load (8 courses per year).
Indicative fees are a guide for comparison only based on current conditions and available data. You should not rely on indicative fees. More information on fees can be found at the UNSW fees website.
Indicative fees to complete the program have been calculated based on a percentage increase for every year of the program. Fee increases are assessed annually and may exceed the indicative figures listed here.
Indicative fees to complete the program include tuition plus an estimate of study-related costs of approximately $1,000 per year. To find out more about other costs, visit UNSW International.
At UNSW, we award over $83 million in scholarships each year. We pride ourselves on rewarding excellence and making university accessible to students from all walks of life. Whether you’re a domestic or international student, our range of scholarships, prizes and awards can support your journey.

      Overview
  









This program is commencing in 2026.
The Master of Finance is a one to two-year postgraduate program delivered by Australia’s #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Developed in close consultation with the finance sector, this program exposes you to the latest thinking and research in finance.
With two entry points, students with a degree in a field other than finance can join the two-year program. Finance undergraduates who want to study advanced topics can choose the one-year option. 









      Key features
  









Put theory into practice
This course will help you develop a foundation of strong critical thinking and problem-solving skills. You'll have opportunities to apply your learnings in real-life settings, helping you feel confident in making financial decisions. 
Hone your specialty
Our program allows you to tailor your expertise to your chosen career path. Choose from three specialisations: Funds Management, Corporate Finance & Investment Banking and Financial Technology, or hand-pick your own finance electives. 
Grow strong industry connections
You'll be taught the latest theories and techniques by industry-leading academics and researchers, enhancing your educational and social skills. You'll also get access to the best networking functions, internships and mentors. 
Add a competitive edge to your career
UNSW Finance graduates are highly sought-after in the workforce. The skills learned in this program are in-demand in many fields, particularly in the corporate setting. 









      Why study at UNSW?
  










We are ranked Australia's #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Receive a business education that leads the way in career impact, quality and reputation.
Progress your finance career at a university ranked #1 in Australia and #22 globally for accounting and finance (QS World University Rankings by Subject, 2025).
Strong industry connections ensuring relevant knowledge, skills and experience.
Career Accelerator is an opportunity unique to UNSW Business School students and provides networking, mentoring and internship opportunities.
Join a global top 20 university (QS World University Rankings, 2024–2026) to unlock opportunities and networks worldwide.

      Entry requirements
  













The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications.
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  













 
You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on your educational background and citizenship. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.
If you’re completing an Australian Year 12 qualification (e.g. NSW HSC or equivalent), you do not need to provide anything extra to prove your proficiency. Your qualification will be used as evidence of your English proficiency.
If you do need to provide evidence of your English proficiency, this will be indicated in your application. You can prove this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.

Note: Applicants from non-211 universities in China wishing to study Postgraduate Coursework in the UNSW Business School, must achieve a minimum overall average of 88 in their current university’s grading system. This is equivalent to an 85% Australian scaled average.

English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.

If English is not your first language, you’ll need to provide proof of your English proficiency before you can be given an offer to study at UNSW. You can do this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

      What will I study?
  









UNSW is introducing a new academic calendar from 2028.
We are moving to a new flex-semester calendar. What does this mean for your studies? 










            Learn more
          




















      Program structure
  









This program provides the skills and experience you need to tailor your qualification to your career goals.

Students who joined the program through Pathway 1 must finish the Stage 1 courses before moving on to Stage 2 courses.
Students commencing from Pathway 2 don’t have to complete Stage 1 courses and can immediately move on to Stage 2. 










      Full program structure
  









At UNSW, each university year has three terms and an optional summer study period. Full-time students can typically fit two or three courses in one term and one course in the summer term.
Below is a summary of what you will study in the Master of Finance:
Stage 1 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

Foundation data analysis courses
Foundation core courses
Foundation elective courses
Additional finance electives

Stage 2 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

4 core courses
Optional specialisation or finance electives. *Students who don’t undertake a specialisation will do additional electives​.

For more information on the coursework, electives and specialisations please see the UNSW Online Handbook. 








            Go to the handbook
          





















      Future careers
  









As a Master of Finance student, you’ll learn the theories and practical techniques specific to your career and professional growth. With internships, mentorships and networking opportunities, you can participate in hands-on learning both in and out of the classroom. Accelerate your career with Australia’s university ranked #1 for employment outcomes (QS World University Rankings, 2026).









      Potential careers
  










Banking Professional
Corporate Treasury
Financial Advisor
Financial Broker
Funds Management
International Finance
Investment Banking

UNSW Business School's Career Accelerator portfolio offers students exclusive access to a suite of for-credit, co-curricular and business experience opportunities to kick start your career.










      Accreditation
  









You may be eligible for Associate membership with the Financial Services Institute of Australasia (FINSIA) upon completion of this degree.

















      How to apply
  









This program is commencing in 2026.














Applications must be submitted through our Apply Online portal. We encourage you to submit your completed application as early as possible to ensure it will be processed in time for your preferred term. Some high-demand programs and Faculties with limited places may have an earlier application deadline or commencement date. Find out more.

Some high-demand programs with limited places, may have an earlier application deadline or may have an earlier commencement date. For details, visit the international admissions information page.

      Key features
  









Put theory into practice
This course will help you develop a foundation of strong critical thinking and problem-solving skills. You'll have opportunities to apply your learnings in real-life settings, helping you feel confident in making financial decisions. 
Hone your specialty
Our program allows you to tailor your expertise to your chosen career path. Choose from three specialisations: Funds Management, Corporate Finance & Investment Banking and Financial Technology, or hand-pick your own finance electives. 
Grow strong industry connections
You'll be taught the latest theories and techniques by industry-leading academics and researchers, enhancing your educational and social skills. You'll also get access to the best networking functions, internships and mentors. 
Add a competitive edge to your career
UNSW Finance graduates are highly sought-after in the workforce. The skills learned in this program are in-demand in many fields, particularly in the corporate setting. 









      Why study at UNSW?
  










We are ranked Australia's #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Receive a business education that leads the way in career impact, quality and reputation.
Progress your finance career at a university ranked #1 in Australia and #22 globally for accounting and finance (QS World University Rankings by Subject, 2025).
Strong industry connections ensuring relevant knowledge, skills and experience.
Career Accelerator is an opportunity unique to UNSW Business School students and provides networking, mentoring and internship opportunities.
Join a global top 20 university (QS World University Rankings, 2024–2026) to unlock opportunities and networks worldwide.

This program is commencing in 2026.
The Master of Finance is a one to two-year postgraduate program delivered by Australia’s #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Developed in close consultation with the finance sector, this program exposes you to the latest thinking and research in finance.
With two entry points, students with a degree in a field other than finance can join the two-year program. Finance undergraduates who want to study advanced topics can choose the one-year option.
Put theory into practice

Hone your specialty
Our program allows you to tailor your expertise to your chosen career path. Choose from three specialisations: Funds Management, Corporate Finance & Investment Banking and Financial Technology, or hand-pick your own finance electives. 
Grow strong industry connections
You'll be taught the latest theories and techniques by industry-leading academics and researchers, enhancing your educational and social skills. You'll also get access to the best networking functions, internships and mentors. 
Add a competitive edge to your career
UNSW Finance graduates are highly sought-after in the workforce. The skills learned in this program are in-demand in many fields, particularly in the corporate setting.

Entry requirements
  













The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications.
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  













 
You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on your educational background and citizenship. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.
If you’re completing an Australian Year 12 qualification (e.g. NSW HSC or equivalent), you do not need to provide anything extra to prove your proficiency. Your qualification will be used as evidence of your English proficiency.
If you do need to provide evidence of your English proficiency, this will be indicated in your application. You can prove this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page. 

















The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications. The entry requirements for the two pathways include:
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Students who are not graduates of Australian or New Zealand universities
For students who studied at overseas universities, a credit average grade (65% or higher) is the normal academic requirement for Australian universities. You can calculate the equivalent using the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator. Details on assessment will be determined by your grading system so ensure this is attached to your transcript when you apply.

Note: Applicants from non-211 universities in China wishing to study Postgraduate Coursework in the UNSW Business School, must achieve a minimum overall average of 88 in their current university’s grading system. This is equivalent to an 85% Australian scaled average.
Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted  exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  














You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on whether you are from an English-speaking background or non-English speaking background. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.

If English is not your first language, you’ll need to provide proof of your English proficiency before you can be given an offer to study at UNSW. You can do this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.

What will I study?
  









UNSW is introducing a new academic calendar from 2028.
We are moving to a new flex-semester calendar. What does this mean for your studies? 










            Learn more
          




















      Program structure
  









This program provides the skills and experience you need to tailor your qualification to your career goals.

Students who joined the program through Pathway 1 must finish the Stage 1 courses before moving on to Stage 2 courses.
Students commencing from Pathway 2 don’t have to complete Stage 1 courses and can immediately move on to Stage 2. 










      Full program structure
  









At UNSW, each university year has three terms and an optional summer study period. Full-time students can typically fit two or three courses in one term and one course in the summer term.
Below is a summary of what you will study in the Master of Finance:
Stage 1 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

Foundation data analysis courses
Foundation core courses
Foundation elective courses
Additional finance electives

Stage 2 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

4 core courses
Optional specialisation or finance electives. *Students who don’t undertake a specialisation will do additional electives​.

For more information on the coursework, electives and specialisations please see the UNSW Online Handbook.

      Overview
  









This program is commencing in 2026.
The Master of Finance is a one to two-year postgraduate program delivered by Australia’s #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Developed in close consultation with the finance sector, this program exposes you to the latest thinking and research in finance.
With two entry points, students with a degree in a field other than finance can join the two-year program. Finance undergraduates who want to study advanced topics can choose the one-year option. 









      Key features
  









Put theory into practice
This course will help you develop a foundation of strong critical thinking and problem-solving skills. You'll have opportunities to apply your learnings in real-life settings, helping you feel confident in making financial decisions. 
Hone your specialty
Our program allows you to tailor your expertise to your chosen career path. Choose from three specialisations: Funds Management, Corporate Finance & Investment Banking and Financial Technology, or hand-pick your own finance electives. 
Grow strong industry connections
You'll be taught the latest theories and techniques by industry-leading academics and researchers, enhancing your educational and social skills. You'll also get access to the best networking functions, internships and mentors. 
Add a competitive edge to your career
UNSW Finance graduates are highly sought-after in the workforce. The skills learned in this program are in-demand in many fields, particularly in the corporate setting. 









      Why study at UNSW?
  










We are ranked Australia's #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Receive a business education that leads the way in career impact, quality and reputation.
Progress your finance career at a university ranked #1 in Australia and #22 globally for accounting and finance (QS World University Rankings by Subject, 2025).
Strong industry connections ensuring relevant knowledge, skills and experience.
Career Accelerator is an opportunity unique to UNSW Business School students and provides networking, mentoring and internship opportunities.
Join a global top 20 university (QS World University Rankings, 2024–2026) to unlock opportunities and networks worldwide.

      Entry requirements
  













The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications.
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  













 
You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on your educational background and citizenship. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.
If you’re completing an Australian Year 12 qualification (e.g. NSW HSC or equivalent), you do not need to provide anything extra to prove your proficiency. Your qualification will be used as evidence of your English proficiency.
If you do need to provide evidence of your English proficiency, this will be indicated in your application. You can prove this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page. 

















The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications. The entry requirements for the two pathways include:
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Students who are not graduates of Australian or New Zealand universities
For students who studied at overseas universities, a credit average grade (65% or higher) is the normal academic requirement for Australian universities. You can calculate the equivalent using the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator. Details on assessment will be determined by your grading system so ensure this is attached to your transcript when you apply.

Note: Applicants from non-211 universities in China wishing to study Postgraduate Coursework in the UNSW Business School, must achieve a minimum overall average of 88 in their current university’s grading system. This is equivalent to an 85% Australian scaled average.
Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted  exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  














You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on whether you are from an English-speaking background or non-English speaking background. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.

If English is not your first language, you’ll need to provide proof of your English proficiency before you can be given an offer to study at UNSW. You can do this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.

      Program structure
  









This program provides the skills and experience you need to tailor your qualification to your career goals.

Students who joined the program through Pathway 1 must finish the Stage 1 courses before moving on to Stage 2 courses.
Students commencing from Pathway 2 don’t have to complete Stage 1 courses and can immediately move on to Stage 2. 










      Full program structure
  









At UNSW, each university year has three terms and an optional summer study period. Full-time students can typically fit two or three courses in one term and one course in the summer term.
Below is a summary of what you will study in the Master of Finance:
Stage 1 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

Foundation data analysis courses
Foundation core courses
Foundation elective courses
Additional finance electives

Stage 2 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

4 core courses
Optional specialisation or finance electives. *Students who don’t undertake a specialisation will do additional electives​.

For more information on the coursework, electives and specialisations please see the UNSW Online Handbook. 








            Go to the handbook
          





















      Future careers
  









As a Master of Finance student, you’ll learn the theories and practical techniques specific to your career and professional growth. With internships, mentorships and networking opportunities, you can participate in hands-on learning both in and out of the classroom. Accelerate your career with Australia’s university ranked #1 for employment outcomes (QS World University Rankings, 2026).









      Potential careers
  










Banking Professional
Corporate Treasury
Financial Advisor
Financial Broker
Funds Management
International Finance
Investment Banking

UNSW Business School's Career Accelerator portfolio offers students exclusive access to a suite of for-credit, co-curricular and business experience opportunities to kick start your career.










      Accreditation
  









You may be eligible for Associate membership with the Financial Services Institute of Australasia (FINSIA) upon completion of this degree.

Overview
  









This program is commencing in 2026.
The Master of Finance is a one to two-year postgraduate program delivered by Australia’s #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Developed in close consultation with the finance sector, this program exposes you to the latest thinking and research in finance.
With two entry points, students with a degree in a field other than finance can join the two-year program. Finance undergraduates who want to study advanced topics can choose the one-year option. 









      Key features
  









Put theory into practice
This course will help you develop a foundation of strong critical thinking and problem-solving skills. You'll have opportunities to apply your learnings in real-life settings, helping you feel confident in making financial decisions. 
Hone your specialty
Our program allows you to tailor your expertise to your chosen career path. Choose from three specialisations: Funds Management, Corporate Finance & Investment Banking and Financial Technology, or hand-pick your own finance electives. 
Grow strong industry connections
You'll be taught the latest theories and techniques by industry-leading academics and researchers, enhancing your educational and social skills. You'll also get access to the best networking functions, internships and mentors. 
Add a competitive edge to your career
UNSW Finance graduates are highly sought-after in the workforce. The skills learned in this program are in-demand in many fields, particularly in the corporate setting. 









      Why study at UNSW?
  










We are ranked Australia's #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Receive a business education that leads the way in career impact, quality and reputation.
Progress your finance career at a university ranked #1 in Australia and #22 globally for accounting and finance (QS World University Rankings by Subject, 2025).
Strong industry connections ensuring relevant knowledge, skills and experience.
Career Accelerator is an opportunity unique to UNSW Business School students and provides networking, mentoring and internship opportunities.
Join a global top 20 university (QS World University Rankings, 2024–2026) to unlock opportunities and networks worldwide.

Entry requirements
  













The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications.
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  













 
You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on your educational background and citizenship. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.
If you’re completing an Australian Year 12 qualification (e.g. NSW HSC or equivalent), you do not need to provide anything extra to prove your proficiency. Your qualification will be used as evidence of your English proficiency.
If you do need to provide evidence of your English proficiency, this will be indicated in your application. You can prove this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.

If English is not your first language, you’ll need to provide proof of your English proficiency before you can be given an offer to study at UNSW. You can do this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.

Which applies to you? *
The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications. The entry requirements for the two pathways include:
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Students who are not graduates of Australian or New Zealand universities
For students who studied at overseas universities, a credit average grade (65% or higher) is the normal academic requirement for Australian universities. You can calculate the equivalent using the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator. Details on assessment will be determined by your grading system so ensure this is attached to your transcript when you apply.

Note: Applicants from non-211 universities in China wishing to study Postgraduate Coursework in the UNSW Business School, must achieve a minimum overall average of 88 in their current university’s grading system. This is equivalent to an 85% Australian scaled average.
Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted  exemption for 12 UOC.

      Program structure
  









This program provides the skills and experience you need to tailor your qualification to your career goals.

Students who joined the program through Pathway 1 must finish the Stage 1 courses before moving on to Stage 2 courses.
Students commencing from Pathway 2 don’t have to complete Stage 1 courses and can immediately move on to Stage 2. 










      Full program structure
  









At UNSW, each university year has three terms and an optional summer study period. Full-time students can typically fit two or three courses in one term and one course in the summer term.
Below is a summary of what you will study in the Master of Finance:
Stage 1 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

Foundation data analysis courses
Foundation core courses
Foundation elective courses
Additional finance electives

Stage 2 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

4 core courses
Optional specialisation or finance electives. *Students who don’t undertake a specialisation will do additional electives​.

For more information on the coursework, electives and specialisations please see the UNSW Online Handbook.

Overview
  









This program is commencing in 2026.
The Master of Finance is a one to two-year postgraduate program delivered by Australia’s #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Developed in close consultation with the finance sector, this program exposes you to the latest thinking and research in finance.
With two entry points, students with a degree in a field other than finance can join the two-year program. Finance undergraduates who want to study advanced topics can choose the one-year option. 









      Key features
  









Put theory into practice
This course will help you develop a foundation of strong critical thinking and problem-solving skills. You'll have opportunities to apply your learnings in real-life settings, helping you feel confident in making financial decisions. 
Hone your specialty
Our program allows you to tailor your expertise to your chosen career path. Choose from three specialisations: Funds Management, Corporate Finance & Investment Banking and Financial Technology, or hand-pick your own finance electives. 
Grow strong industry connections
You'll be taught the latest theories and techniques by industry-leading academics and researchers, enhancing your educational and social skills. You'll also get access to the best networking functions, internships and mentors. 
Add a competitive edge to your career
UNSW Finance graduates are highly sought-after in the workforce. The skills learned in this program are in-demand in many fields, particularly in the corporate setting. 









      Why study at UNSW?
  










We are ranked Australia's #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Receive a business education that leads the way in career impact, quality and reputation.
Progress your finance career at a university ranked #1 in Australia and #22 globally for accounting and finance (QS World University Rankings by Subject, 2025).
Strong industry connections ensuring relevant knowledge, skills and experience.
Career Accelerator is an opportunity unique to UNSW Business School students and provides networking, mentoring and internship opportunities.
Join a global top 20 university (QS World University Rankings, 2024–2026) to unlock opportunities and networks worldwide.

Entry requirements
  













The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications.
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  













 
You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on your educational background and citizenship. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.
If you’re completing an Australian Year 12 qualification (e.g. NSW HSC or equivalent), you do not need to provide anything extra to prove your proficiency. Your qualification will be used as evidence of your English proficiency.
If you do need to provide evidence of your English proficiency, this will be indicated in your application. You can prove this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.

If you do need to provide evidence of your English proficiency, this will be indicated in your application. You can prove this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.
The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications.
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted exemption for 12 UOC.

The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications. The entry requirements for the two pathways include:
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Students who are not graduates of Australian or New Zealand universities
For students who studied at overseas universities, a credit average grade (65% or higher) is the normal academic requirement for Australian universities. You can calculate the equivalent using the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator. Details on assessment will be determined by your grading system so ensure this is attached to your transcript when you apply.

Note: Applicants from non-211 universities in China wishing to study Postgraduate Coursework in the UNSW Business School, must achieve a minimum overall average of 88 in their current university’s grading system. This is equivalent to an 85% Australian scaled average.
Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted  exemption for 12 UOC.

What will I study?
  









UNSW is introducing a new academic calendar from 2028.
We are moving to a new flex-semester calendar. What does this mean for your studies? 










            Learn more
          




















      Program structure
  









This program provides the skills and experience you need to tailor your qualification to your career goals.

Students who joined the program through Pathway 1 must finish the Stage 1 courses before moving on to Stage 2 courses.
Students commencing from Pathway 2 don’t have to complete Stage 1 courses and can immediately move on to Stage 2. 










      Full program structure
  









At UNSW, each university year has three terms and an optional summer study period. Full-time students can typically fit two or three courses in one term and one course in the summer term.
Below is a summary of what you will study in the Master of Finance:
Stage 1 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

Foundation data analysis courses
Foundation core courses
Foundation elective courses
Additional finance electives

Stage 2 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

4 core courses
Optional specialisation or finance electives. *Students who don’t undertake a specialisation will do additional electives​.

For more information on the coursework, electives and specialisations please see the UNSW Online Handbook.

Future careers
  









As a Master of Finance student, you’ll learn the theories and practical techniques specific to your career and professional growth. With internships, mentorships and networking opportunities, you can participate in hands-on learning both in and out of the classroom. Accelerate your career with Australia’s university ranked #1 for employment outcomes (QS World University Rankings, 2026).









      Potential careers
  










Banking Professional
Corporate Treasury
Financial Advisor
Financial Broker
Funds Management
International Finance
Investment Banking

UNSW Business School's Career Accelerator portfolio offers students exclusive access to a suite of for-credit, co-curricular and business experience opportunities to kick start your career.










      Accreditation
  









You may be eligible for Associate membership with the Financial Services Institute of Australasia (FINSIA) upon completion of this degree.

This program is commencing in 2026.
The Master of Finance is a one to two-year postgraduate program delivered by Australia’s #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Developed in close consultation with the finance sector, this program exposes you to the latest thinking and research in finance.
With two entry points, students with a degree in a field other than finance can join the two-year program. Finance undergraduates who want to study advanced topics can choose the one-year option.
Put theory into practice
This course will help you develop a foundation of strong critical thinking and problem-solving skills. You'll have opportunities to apply your learnings in real-life settings, helping you feel confident in making financial decisions. 
Hone your specialty
Our program allows you to tailor your expertise to your chosen career path. Choose from three specialisations: Funds Management, Corporate Finance & Investment Banking and Financial Technology, or hand-pick your own finance electives. 
Grow strong industry connections
You'll be taught the latest theories and techniques by industry-leading academics and researchers, enhancing your educational and social skills. You'll also get access to the best networking functions, internships and mentors. 
Add a competitive edge to your career
UNSW Finance graduates are highly sought-after in the workforce. The skills learned in this program are in-demand in many fields, particularly in the corporate setting.
We are ranked Australia's #1 Business School (Australian Financial Review (AFR) Boss, 2024).
Receive a business education that leads the way in career impact, quality and reputation.
Progress your finance career at a university ranked #1 in Australia and #22 globally for accounting and finance (QS World University Rankings by Subject, 2025).
Strong industry connections ensuring relevant knowledge, skills and experience.
Career Accelerator is an opportunity unique to UNSW Business School students and provides networking, mentoring and internship opportunities.
Join a global top 20 university (QS World University Rankings, 2024–2026) to unlock opportunities and networks worldwide.
Want to see more from UNSW Business School?

The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications.
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  













 
You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on your educational background and citizenship. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.
If you’re completing an Australian Year 12 qualification (e.g. NSW HSC or equivalent), you do not need to provide anything extra to prove your proficiency. Your qualification will be used as evidence of your English proficiency.
If you do need to provide evidence of your English proficiency, this will be indicated in your application. You can prove this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.

The Master of Finance has two entry points, which require varying qualifications. The entry requirements for the two pathways include:
Pathway 1 | Two-year program
You will need:

A bachelor’s degree in any field with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator.

Pathway 2 | One-year accelerated program
You’ll need the following:

A recognised bachelor’s degree (or equivalent qualification) with a credit average (65% or higher) as determined by the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator; and
A major (at least seven courses) in finance within the bachelor’s degree.

Students who are not graduates of Australian or New Zealand universities
For students who studied at overseas universities, a credit average grade (65% or higher) is the normal academic requirement for Australian universities. You can calculate the equivalent using the UNSW Postgraduate Coursework Entry Calculator. Details on assessment will be determined by your grading system so ensure this is attached to your transcript when you apply.

Note: Applicants from non-211 universities in China wishing to study Postgraduate Coursework in the UNSW Business School, must achieve a minimum overall average of 88 in their current university’s grading system. This is equivalent to an 85% Australian scaled average.
Recognition of Prior Learning
If you've successfully completed the CFA program by passing all three levels of CFA exam, you may be granted  exemption for 12 UOC.









      English language requirements
  














You may be asked to provide evidence of your English proficiency to study at UNSW depending on whether you are from an English-speaking background or non-English speaking background. English language skills are vitally important for coping with lectures, tutorials, assignments and examinations - this is why UNSW requires a minimum English language competency for enrolment.

If English is not your first language, you’ll need to provide proof of your English proficiency before you can be given an offer to study at UNSW. You can do this by providing evidence that you meet one or more of the following criteria:

English language tests and university English courses
Prior study in the medium of English
Other qualifications

If you need to improve your English skills before you start your degree, UNSW College’s Academic English Programs are for you. The programs are suitable for various English levels and help you prepare for university studies and life in Australia.
For more details, visit the English Language Requirements page.

This program provides the skills and experience you need to tailor your qualification to your career goals.

Students who joined the program through Pathway 1 must finish the Stage 1 courses before moving on to Stage 2 courses.
Students commencing from Pathway 2 don’t have to complete Stage 1 courses and can immediately move on to Stage 2.
At UNSW, each university year has three terms and an optional summer study period. Full-time students can typically fit two or three courses in one term and one course in the summer term.
Below is a summary of what you will study in the Master of Finance:
Stage 1 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

Foundation data analysis courses
Foundation core courses
Foundation elective courses
Additional finance electives

Stage 2 | 48 units of credit (UOC)

4 core courses
Optional specialisation or finance electives. *Students who don’t undertake a specialisation will do additional electives​.

For more information on the coursework, electives and specialisations please see the UNSW Online Handbook.

pages.content:
[HEADING] Academic English
[HEADING] Improve your English skills before you start university, with our Academic English Programs. They help you communicate effectively, get familiar with expectations at university, succeed in your studies and reach your goals.
[HEADING] Your journey with an English Program
[HEADING] Learn with UNSW College
[HEADING] Choose your level
[HEADING] Prepare for the next step
[HEADING] Supportive, practical and engaging
[HEADING] Communicate confidently with Mentor AI
[HEADING] Academic English programs
[HEADING] University English Entry Course (UEEC)
[HEADING] Foundation English Entry Course (FEEC)
[HEADING] Tertiary Orientation Program
[HEADING] Essential Academic English
[HEADING] Student Guide
[HEADING] Student Life
[HEADING] Living in Sydney
[HEADING] Accommodation
[HEADING] Pathway Finder
[HEADING] Student Services
[HEADING] Under 18 Care
[HEADING] Student & Alumni Stories
[HEADING] Scholarships
We have a range of programs to choose from, based on your individual needs and the study path you want to take. They can also be packaged with our Diploma and Foundation Studies programs, and UNSW degrees.
Our courses are suitable for various English levels and help develop your academic language skills quickly. Choose the option that suits your current ability level and future plans.
If you need to meet the English entry requirements for one of our pathway programs or a UNSW degree, these flexible courses will help you get there.
Learn English at your level in small classes with lots of support, plus regular feedback and assessments. Industry‑leading teachers will help you develop critical thinking skills through engaging and interactive classes, both online and face-to-face.
Mentor AI is your personal study buddy designed to help you achieve your English goals. This AI-powered tool is designed to provide you with extended speaking practice and also feedback on your speaking skills!
Record yourself speaking and get instant feedback on grammar, pronunciation, fluency, and even the vocabulary you use. Plus, Mentor includes live, interactive Q&A sessions in real-time, throwing real-world questions your way to help you think on your feet.
Whether it's class discussions or presentations, you'll be ready for anything. Developed by UNSW College experts, Mentor puts you in control of your communication skills, builds your confidence, and gets you ready for success at UNSW.
This intermediate, 10-week course prepares you for our Foundation Studies program. If you pass the FEEC, you do not need to sit any other English tests.
UNSW Global Pty Limited ABN 62 086 418 582 trading as UNSW College™.
Foundation Studies, Academic English and Pre-Masters Program
UNSW College delivers its Foundation Studies, Academic English, and Pre-Masters Program under CRICOS Provider Code 01020K; TEQSA Provider ID: PRV13020 (Institute of Higher Education).
Diplomas
UNSW College delivers its UNSW College Diplomas under CRICOS Provider Code 01020K; TEQSA Provider ID: PRV13020 (Institute of Higher Education). UNSW College delivers UNSW Diplomas on behalf of UNSW Sydney under CRICOS Provider Code 00098G; UNSW Sydney TEQSA Provider ID: PRV12055 (Australian University).
See https://unswcollege.edu.au/esos for more information. © 2025 UNSW Global Pty Limited.
• Search
[GRID_TABLE]
Improve your English skills before you start university, with our Academic English Programs. They help you communicate effectively, get familiar with expectations at university, succeed in your studies and reach your goals. 
We have a range of programs to choose from, based on your individual needs and the study path you want to take. They can also be packaged with our Diploma and Foundation Studies programs, and UNSW degrees. 














      Your journey with an English Program
  






































      Learn with UNSW College
  


















Choose your level 
Our courses are suitable for various English levels and help develop your academic language skills quickly. Choose the option that suits your current ability level and future plans. 

























Prepare for the next step 
If you need to meet the English entry requirements for one of our pathway programs or a UNSW degree, these flexible courses will help you get there. 




















Supportive, practical and engaging 
Learn English at your level in small classes with lots of support, plus regular feedback and assessments. Industry‑leading teachers will help you develop critical thinking skills through engaging and interactive classes, both online and face-to-face. 







































Communicate confidently with Mentor AI





















Mentor AI is your personal study buddy designed to help you achieve your English goals. This AI-powered tool is designed to provide you with extended speaking practice and also feedback on your speaking skills!
Record yourself speaking and get instant feedback on grammar, pronunciation, fluency, and even the vocabulary you use. Plus, Mentor includes live, interactive Q&A sessions in real-time, throwing real-world questions your way to help you think on your feet.
Whether it's class discussions or presentations, you'll be ready for anything. Developed by UNSW College experts, Mentor puts you in control of your communication skills, builds your confidence, and gets you ready for success at UNSW.


























      Academic English programs
  





















                    University English Entry Course (UEEC)
                



                Have you received a conditional offer from UNSW Sydney, but do not meet the UNSW English entry requirements? In 20 weeks or less, this advanced course can help. If you pass the UEEC, you do not need to sit any other English tests.
            


















                    Foundation English Entry Course (FEEC)
                



This intermediate, 10-week course prepares you for our Foundation Studies program. If you pass the FEEC, you do not need to sit any other English tests.

























                    Tertiary Orientation Program
                



                This is an advanced course that runs over five weeks. It’s for students who have a full offer from UNSW but want to strengthen their English language skills before starting university. 
            


















                    Essential Academic English
                



                This 10-week, intermediate course prepares you with the academic English skills you need to enter the University English and Foundation English courses. 
            














































                            Student Guide
                        


                            Download our Student Guide today for more information on our courses, life at UNSW College and how we help you reach your goals. 
                        




















                            Student Life
                        


                            As a UNSW College student, you are connected to the wider UNSW community: active, vibrant and diverse. Discover more about what that means. 
                        




















                            Living in Sydney
                        


                            One of the world’s most liveable cities, Sydney is multicultural, safe, filled of natural beauty and home to many global companies. See what Australia’s iconic harbour city can offer you.  
                        




















                            Accommodation
                        


                            UNSW Sydney has a variety of student accommodation options to suit your needs. Walk to your classes, make new friends and enjoy the amazing Sydney lifestyle. 
                        




















                            Pathway Finder
                        


                            Choose from multiple pathway options that will help you get into your university degree of choice at UNSW Sydney. 
                        




















                            Student Services 
                        


                            We are here to support you while you study with us. Learn more about the many different ways we look after you from your first day to graduation. 
                        




















                            Under 18 Care
                        


                            Many of our students at UNSW College are under 18. If you do not have a parent or guardian to stay with while you are in Sydney, we can help. 
                        




















                            Student & Alumni Stories
                        


                            Hear from the students we have helped along their path to academic success and future careers, as they share their stories about studying with UNSW College.  
                        




















                            Scholarships
                        


                            We have a range of scholarship options available for UNSW College students. Find out how to apply, eligibility criteria and more.

Improve your English skills before you start university, with our Academic English Programs. They help you communicate effectively, get familiar with expectations at university, succeed in your studies and reach your goals. 
We have a range of programs to choose from, based on your individual needs and the study path you want to take. They can also be packaged with our Diploma and Foundation Studies programs, and UNSW degrees. 














      Your journey with an English Program
  






































      Learn with UNSW College
  


















Choose your level 
Our courses are suitable for various English levels and help develop your academic language skills quickly. Choose the option that suits your current ability level and future plans. 

























Prepare for the next step 
If you need to meet the English entry requirements for one of our pathway programs or a UNSW degree, these flexible courses will help you get there. 




















Supportive, practical and engaging 
Learn English at your level in small classes with lots of support, plus regular feedback and assessments. Industry‑leading teachers will help you develop critical thinking skills through engaging and interactive classes, both online and face-to-face. 







































Communicate confidently with Mentor AI





















Mentor AI is your personal study buddy designed to help you achieve your English goals. This AI-powered tool is designed to provide you with extended speaking practice and also feedback on your speaking skills!
Record yourself speaking and get instant feedback on grammar, pronunciation, fluency, and even the vocabulary you use. Plus, Mentor includes live, interactive Q&A sessions in real-time, throwing real-world questions your way to help you think on your feet.
Whether it's class discussions or presentations, you'll be ready for anything. Developed by UNSW College experts, Mentor puts you in control of your communication skills, builds your confidence, and gets you ready for success at UNSW.


























      Academic English programs
  





















                    University English Entry Course (UEEC)
                



                Have you received a conditional offer from UNSW Sydney, but do not meet the UNSW English entry requirements? In 20 weeks or less, this advanced course can help. If you pass the UEEC, you do not need to sit any other English tests.
            


















                    Foundation English Entry Course (FEEC)
                



This intermediate, 10-week course prepares you for our Foundation Studies program. If you pass the FEEC, you do not need to sit any other English tests.

























                    Tertiary Orientation Program
                



                This is an advanced course that runs over five weeks. It’s for students who have a full offer from UNSW but want to strengthen their English language skills before starting university. 
            


















                    Essential Academic English
                



                This 10-week, intermediate course prepares you with the academic English skills you need to enter the University English and Foundation English courses.

pages.title: Academic English Course Overview | UNSW College

pages.content:
[HEADING] How to Apply
[HEADING] Hear From Our Students
[HEADING] Thinking of joining us at UNSW?
Scholarships for local and international students, including high school leavers, other future students and current UNSW students.
Contact the Graduate Research School
You need your zID, UAC number or board of studies number with a leading "1" e.g. "112345678" to register.
You can apply for as many scholarships as you are eligible for.
Complete your profile, including general questions used for all applications. Some scholarships may require your to answer more specific questions. Upload your support documentation and preview your application before submitting.
When you have completed your application, click 'Submit'. You will receive an email to confirm your application has been submitted successfully. All applicants are notified of the outcome of their application via the email address provided.
Ensure your completed application is submitted by the due date. Late applications will not be accepted.
To anyone that wants to pursue sport at an elite level whilst continuing their studies I can't recommend UNSW highly enough, it has far exceeded my expectations in the support and flexibility provided to Athletes whilst also providing an excellent academic program.
Ben Lexcen Sports Scholarship
Receiving a scholarship was such a privilege and I really wanted to make the most of this opportunity. My scholarship really drove me to do my best in all my subjects as well as to get the most out of uni life, hence all the clubs I joined where I met so many great people.
Explorer Award
Get as involved as possible! It is so easy to get caught up with study and just focus on your subjects, however, there are so many incredible opportunities available at UNSW which really develop you as a person.
Magnitude Foundation Scholarship
New Colombo Plan Ambassador
Having grown up in Singapore, Australia, India and Indonesia, it was imperative that the university I chose to spend the next four years at, would continue to stimulate my global awareness and international exposure. Not only that, but as one of few young, driven women in a male-dominated field, I needed to know that I will be given equal opportunities and possibilities.
Tidswell Family Women in Engineering Scholarship
Doing my Honours degree in ecology at UNSW provided me the opportunity to work with world class scientists to help save some of the most threatened species in Australia. Throughout my undergraduate, I have been taught to become more than just a researcher but also a communicator and educator at UNSW.
Sonja Huddle Award
I elected to study Electrical Engineering for several reasons. Foremost was my strength in maths, physic and electrotechnology in high school, particularly in the electrical components of the latter two courses. I enjoyed these components so much that I asked my physics teacher to let me use the labs during breaks and after school - I'd bring in old TVs and microwaves, take them apart and use their parts in electrical circuits.
Faculty of Engineering Rural Scholarship
Department of Education and Training/UNSW Rural Assistance Scheme
Being able to hold a Ben Lexcen sporting scholarship has really helped my academic and sporting life. The access to the gym and pool on campus, as well as the support from the scholarship staff and UNSW sport clubs has really advanced my ability to train and balance my time.
Ben Lexcen Sports Scholarship
The support that scholarships offer in terms of helping students with the cost of their degrees and living expenses in Sydney is remarkable. Obviously it is nice for your personal efforts to be recognised
Alumni Association Scholarship
Sam Cracknell Memorial Sports Scholarship
I chose UNSW because of the inclusive atmosphere and because I felt it was really at the forefront of academics, research and innovation. I wanted a university that was looking to the future and presenting its students with exciting
Scientia Scholarship
Academic Achievement Awards (AAA)
I am fortunate enough to study medicine. One aspect of medicine that appealed to me is that medicine presents the opportunity to positively contribute to the health and wellbeing of those around me. Also appealing to me was, the notion that medicine, by nature, is a dynamic degree, constantly evolving with advancements in knowledge every year.
Balnaves Foundation Indigenous Medical Scholarship
Having a scholarship gave me the funds to be able to move into a college on campus! This has cut down my travel time by 3 hours, allowing me to get more work in and be more active in UNSW societies.
DSTO Undergraduate Scholarship for Females in Science and Engineering
Honourable Jack Beale Scholarship in Engineering
My other piece of advice is to remember that, on a philosophical level, success cannot exist without failure. When you make mistakes, and it is inevitable that you will, I’d really recommend that you reflect on them and to think about what you could do better next time.
New Colombo Plan Scholarship
Islamic Society Scholarship
All-Rounder Scholarship
Alumni Association Scholarship

• I chose UNSW because of the inclusive atmosphere and because I felt it was really at the forefront of academics, research and innovation. I wanted a university that was looking to the future and presenting its students with exciting 



 
 Nechama  Basserabie

Academic Achievement Awards (AAA)
• I am fortunate enough to study medicine. One aspect of medicine that appealed to me is that medicine presents the opportunity to positively contribute to the health and wellbeing of those around me. Also appealing to me was, the notion that medicine, by nature, is a dynamic degree, constantly evolving with advancements in knowledge every year. 



 
 Benjamin  Jones

• Having a scholarship gave me the funds to be able to move into a college on campus! This has cut down my travel time by 3 hours, allowing me to get more work in and be more active in UNSW societies.
