Post-Secondary or Tertiary Qualifications in English
            






Study Abroad and Exchange students who have successfully completed at least one consecutive year of full-time study study at an AQF Bachelor level or higher from a recognised institution where the sole language of instruction and assessment was English, may not be required to undertake a language test if they can provide a statement or certificate from their home university confirming this. This can be in the form of a statement or certificate issued by the Registrar (or equivalent) on official headed paper.  

The study must have been completed no more than two years prior to the commencement of your Study Abroad or Exchange program at UNSW.
Post-Secondary or Tertiary Qualifications in English
Post-Secondary or Tertiary Qualifications in English
Study Abroad and Exchange students who have successfully completed at least one consecutive year of full-time study study at an AQF Bachelor level or higher from a recognised institution where the sole language of instruction and assessment was English, may not be required to undertake a language test if they can provide a statement or certificate from their home university confirming this. This can be in the form of a statement or certificate issued by the Registrar (or equivalent) on official headed paper.  

The study must have been completed no more than two years prior to the commencement of your Study Abroad or Exchange program at UNSW.
University English Entry Course (UEEC)
            






If you don’t quite meet the UNSW English language requirements, you may wish to consider undertaking English language study through the UNSW College University English Entry Course (UEEC) program. You can apply to UEEC to undertake English language study prior to your study abroad or exchange.  You will be provided with a conditional study abroad or exchange offer and you can demonstrate you meet our English language requirements by taking the UEEC program and achieving the minimum grade of C+ and C in writing.  You are responsible for paying any tuition fees directly to UEEC.
University English Entry Course (UEEC)
University English Entry Course (UEEC)
If you don’t quite meet the UNSW English language requirements, you may wish to consider undertaking English language study through the UNSW College University English Entry Course (UEEC) program. You can apply to UEEC to undertake English language study prior to your study abroad or exchange.  You will be provided with a conditional study abroad or exchange offer and you can demonstrate you meet our English language requirements by taking the UEEC program and achieving the minimum grade of C+ and C in writing.  You are responsible for paying any tuition fees directly to UEEC.
Things to know
  









                List of Recognised English Speaking Countries
            






UNSW recognises the follow countries as English-speaking: American Samoa, Australia, Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Botswana, Canada, Fiji, Gibraltar, Ghana, Guyana, Ireland, Jamaica, Kenya, Lesotho, Liberia, New Zealand, Nigeria, Papua New Guinea, Singapore, Solomon Islands, South Africa, The Gambia, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, United Kingdom (including Northern Ireland), United States of America, Zambia, Zimbabwe.








                Conditional Offers
            






If your application does not meet our English language requirements, but you are otherwise eligible for admission to your desired course, you will be issued a Conditional Letter of Offer.
A full Offer for admission will be issued when you submit documents which demonstrate that you meet our English language requirements.
Conditional Offers based on English language requirements are not offered to UAC applicants for domestic undergraduate or postgraduate coursework programs and any Higher Degree Research applicants. 








                Conditional Package Offers
            






UNSW College has university pathway programs that provide a seamless transition to UNSW Sydney so you can achieve your academic and career goals including the University English Entry Course.
With a Conditional Package Offer, you will be able to apply for a student visa for the duration of UNSW College’s University English Entry Course (UEEC) and your UNSW course.
The package offer is only valid for UNSW College’s UEEC and this depends on whether you are accepted into the UNSW College.
Conditional package offers are not offered for entry to the Bachelor of Education (any program), Graduate Diploma in Psychology, Master of Psychology (including combined PhD/Master) or Master of Teaching (Primary and Secondary).








                Visa Requirements for International Applicants
            






For advice on applying for a student visa, visit the Department of Home Affairs.

Study Abroad & Exchange students
To ensure students have the best possible experience at UNSW and to maximise their chances of personal and academic success, all students including exchange and study abroad students need to meet our English language requirements.  You can view the list of English-speaking countries here.  
 
If English isn't your first language you will need to provide proof of English proficiency at time of application and you can do this by providing evidence that you meet one of UNSW’s approved criteria. You should upload your supporting documents to your Study Abroad or Exchange application.  English proficiency is an entry requirement and we cannot accept students without it. 
Here are some ways you can achieve the language requirements.  We recommend you also review the full list of English Language options above.  No other tests or options can be accepted.
English Language Test Scores
            






UNSW accepts English language test scores to meet our English language requirements provided:

You have completed the test no more than two years before your intended start date, and


You achieve the minimum scores for the Study Abroad and Exchange program.  Study Abroad and Exchange students are only required to meet the overall score for IELTS and TOEFL.  You do not need to meet each of the subtests as per a full degree student. 


 IELTS Academic version
only

TOEFL Internet-based Test (iBT)

6.5 overall

90 overall


You should register for your English language test early to avoid delays.

Please note: TOEFL MyBest scores is not a recognised or accepted language test.  The Department of Home Affairs has advised that results from multiple tests cannot be used for meeting English Language proficiency requirements for a student visa.

Postgraduate Stories
Find out how studying a postgraduate degree at UNSW Business School helped our alumni become more employable and establish their career.

















                    5 Ways You Can Benefit From Doing an Internship
                



                An internship goes a long way to getting your foot on the career ladder. You’ll have the chance to experience working in a particular industry, which could give you the edge you need to land your dream job.
            


















                    A Career Change Into Marketing – Two Professionals Share Their Story
                



                ​Two professionals share how they made a career change into marketing, plus the skills you need to succeed in this dynamic industry.
            


















                    Brooke Shaw Was Five Years Into Her Role but Ready for a New Challenge
                



                Working in a fast-paced environment as a management consultant, Brooke Shaw wanted to develop her knowledge and gain expertise that would advance her career. 
            


















                    Discover Growing Trends With Business Analytics
                



                After doing an internship in business analytics, Amanda K Nabilla knew exactly what career she wanted. 
            


















                    Finding his edge: Todd Chapman
                



                Todd Chapman’s desire to #AlwaysBeLearning helped him launch his own management consulting company in Sydney.
            


















                    Five Secrets to Juggling Work, Life and Postgraduate Study
                



                ​It can be daunting to think about balancing work, life and postgraduate study, particularly if you haven’t set foot on a uni campus for some time. But, undertaking further education is easier than you might think.
            


















                    From Financial Analyst to Head of Finance – Frances Summerhayes
                



                Frances Summerhayes wanted to gain high-level analytical skills, as well as financial and commercial insights into industry, when she signed up to a Master of Financial Analysis in 2009.
            


















                    From Police Detective to Risk Management Expert – Read Jason Breton’s Story
                



                From police detective to director of a company that employs over 56,000 people, Jason Breton reflects on how completing a risk management masters enabled him to change careers, and carve out a valuable niche navigating and advising on risk.
            


















                    Genevieve Was Armed With the Skillset and Tools for Employment
                



                Learning to network at UNSW Business School armed Genevieve Castelino with the skillset and tools to apply herself in the workplace.
            


















                    How Can Postgrad Study Help You Achieve Your Career Goals?
                



                Postgraduate study is a great way to advance your career or change to a new profession. We chatted to five UNSW Business School alumni who shared how their postgraduate study has taken their career in a new direction.
            


















                    How Economics Research Is Challenging Views on Refugees
                



                Research coming out of the UNSW School of Economics is changing the way people think about refugees and their impact on the economy. Juan Carlos Carbajal, Associate Professor from the UNSW School of Economics, shares more.
            


















                    How Elaine Wang Landed a Position With Australia’s Largest Investment Bank
                



                ​Elaine Wang shares how a Master of Financial Planning gave her the confidence and professional recognition to forge a promising career in the finance industry.
            


















                    How Financial Analytics Can Help Achieve Good Corporate Governance
                



                ​Mark Humphery-Jenner, Associate Professor from the UNSW School of Finance, explains why research trends are increasingly helping finance professionals navigate real-world issues, including the management of overconfident executives.
            


















                    How One Decision Helped Brooke Shaw Broaden Her Career Horizon
                



                ​Within one year of completing her Master of Commerce (Human Resources Management) degree, Brooke Shaw had been promoted and received a global employee award. Although the best was yet to come.
            


















                    How to balance work, life and postgraduate study
                



                Anna Trikoulis is a manager at PwC for the Private Clients business tax team. She was promoted to the role after completing a UNSW Business School Master of Taxation – and giving birth to her first daughter.
            
























                    How UNSW’s first Business School graduate took every opportunity
                



                To celebrate reaching our 100,000+ alumni milestone, we tracked down the first UNSW Business School graduate. Meet Langer Avery, a pioneering businessman who believed knowledge is power.
            






opens in a new window












                    Isha knew she wanted more than a degree, that’s why she chose UNSW Sydney
                



                The industry connections made during Isha Miglani’s time at UNSW Business School led the alumna to landing her current role as a Film and TV Production Accountant.
            


















                    Mastering the balancing act of postgraduate study
                



                Students who embark on postgraduate study at UNSW Business School can expect to be taught by leading academics and gain strong links to industry.
            


















                    Redesigning the MBA for a rapidly shifting business world
                



                AGSM is adapting its MBA programs to better equip students with the skills and capabilities executives need in a rapidly changing world.
            


















                    Trading classrooms for celebrities
                



                ​UNSW alumnus Anthony Jury used his postgraduate degree to move from teaching to financial planning for high net worth individuals.
            


















                    Want to make the world a better place?
                



                ​So how can you create a career out of making positive global change? Sustainability and social enterprise are the new frontiers of business innovation.
            


















                    What it’s like to do a business placement overseas
                



                Ever wondered what it would be like to go abroad as a student and work on a business issue for a client? Three students share their experiences completing a business placement overseas.
            


















                    What’s a finance postgraduate degree at UNSW like?
                



                Financial Planning alumnus Juan Trevisiol shares that the main contribution to his studies at UNSW Business School was the quality of teaching.
            


















                    Which pitch? 3 minute thesis finalists speed-pitch us their PhD’s
                



                Three Business School PhD candidates and students have been selected as finalists for the UNSW 3 Minute Thesis competition. They’ll pitch their research that covers algorithmic decision-making, change communication, and longevity risk.
            


















                    Why a mentor gives you a career advantage come graduation
                



                Career mentoring is not just for those who have an established career. A mentoring partnership during undergraduate or postgraduate study can broaden your career options, prepare you for the workforce and give you an opportunity to develop professional contacts.
Find out how studying a postgraduate degree at UNSW Business School helped our alumni become more employable and establish their career.
pages.title: Postgraduate stories | Business School - UNSW Sydney

[HEADING] Follow

Undergraduate and postgraduate
• LinkedIn
• Facebook
• Instagram
• TikTok
• YouTube
[GRID_TABLE]
Your roadmap to employability
Undergraduate and postgraduate















            MBA career journey
          
































Explore 
In the Explore phase, you’ll investigate various career paths, types of roles, and industries. This exploration helps you discover a wide range of opportunities and identify areas that align with your interests and strengths. You’ll gain insights into different sectors, job functions, and potential career paths.














Develop 
In the Develop phase, you’ll focus on building the skills and attributes needed for your chosen career plan. This includes technical skills specific to your field and professional skills like communication, teamwork, and problem solving. 

You’ll engage in activities such as Work Integrated Learning, internships, workshops, and coursework all designed to enhance your competencies and prepare you for the professional world.














Achieve 
The Achieve phase focuses on putting your preparation into action. You’ll learn how to apply for jobs, prepare for interviews, and navigate the job market effectively. This phase includes crafting strong applications, practicing interview techniques, and developing strategies for career success. The goal is to help you secure your desired role and thrive in your professional journey.

Upcoming events










            All events
          






























Undergraduate, postgraduate and MBA

Career Conversations: Talking Finance - on the couch with Shirley Bowles

12:00 PM - 1:00 PM
Thinking about a career in finance? Join us for an engaging conversation with a finance industry expert as they share their career journey, key industry trends, and practical advice for success in the finance sector. Whether you're exploring a future in finance or looking to advance your current career, don’t miss this opportunity to learn, ask questions, and connect with industry insights.
Read more






















Build your Career Roadmap

4:00 PM - 5:00 PM
What does your Roadmap look like? And what industry experiences are available to you throughout your degree?    

Whether you’re on the path of early career discovery, or reaching the pointy end of your degree and looking to pack-in real-world experiences before you graduate – Career Accelerator is the go-to for each and every UNSW Business School student.   

In this session, you will find out more about:  

DIGITAL CERTIFICATIONS 
INTERNSHIPS in Australia   
GLOBAL experiences   
MENTORING programs with industry and alumni   
BUSINESS PROJECTS, experiences, skill-up sessions, industry workshops… and more!   

No matter what stage you’re at in your degree, there’s something for everyone. The question is – where to start? The answer: with Career Accelerator! 
Read more






















Ready, Set, Connect!

3:00 PM - 5:00 PM
Lost for words? Freaked out by ‘networking’?
You’re not alone - but we’ve got you.

In this interactive 2-hour workshop, you’ll learn the why and how of effective networking, craft your elevator pitch, and build the confidence to talk about your skills and strengths with impact.

Start by practicing with your peers in a fun, low-pressure setting, then put your skills into action as you connect with industry professionals who’ll share their insights and top takeaways.

Walk in curious — walk out confident!
Read more

You’ll engage in activities such as Work Integrated Learning, internships, workshops, and coursework all designed to enhance your competencies and prepare you for the professional world.

Build your Career Roadmap
Build your Career Roadmap

4:00 PM - 5:00 PM
What does your Roadmap look like? And what industry experiences are available to you throughout your degree?    

Whether you’re on the path of early career discovery, or reaching the pointy end of your degree and looking to pack-in real-world experiences before you graduate – Career Accelerator is the go-to for each and every UNSW Business School student.   

In this session, you will find out more about:  

DIGITAL CERTIFICATIONS 
INTERNSHIPS in Australia   
GLOBAL experiences   
MENTORING programs with industry and alumni   
BUSINESS PROJECTS, experiences, skill-up sessions, industry workshops… and more!   

No matter what stage you’re at in your degree, there’s something for everyone. The question is – where to start? The answer: with Career Accelerator!

Ready, Set, Connect!
Ready, Set, Connect!

3:00 PM - 5:00 PM
Lost for words? Freaked out by ‘networking’?
You’re not alone - but we’ve got you.

In this interactive 2-hour workshop, you’ll learn the why and how of effective networking, craft your elevator pitch, and build the confidence to talk about your skills and strengths with impact.

Start by practicing with your peers in a fun, low-pressure setting, then put your skills into action as you connect with industry professionals who’ll share their insights and top takeaways.

Walk in curious — walk out confident!
Read more

Your roadmap to employability
Undergraduate and postgraduate















            MBA career journey
          
































Explore 
In the Explore phase, you’ll investigate various career paths, types of roles, and industries. This exploration helps you discover a wide range of opportunities and identify areas that align with your interests and strengths. You’ll gain insights into different sectors, job functions, and potential career paths.














Develop 
In the Develop phase, you’ll focus on building the skills and attributes needed for your chosen career plan. This includes technical skills specific to your field and professional skills like communication, teamwork, and problem solving. 

You’ll engage in activities such as Work Integrated Learning, internships, workshops, and coursework all designed to enhance your competencies and prepare you for the professional world.














Achieve 
The Achieve phase focuses on putting your preparation into action. You’ll learn how to apply for jobs, prepare for interviews, and navigate the job market effectively. This phase includes crafting strong applications, practicing interview techniques, and developing strategies for career success. The goal is to help you secure your desired role and thrive in your professional journey.

Whether you’re on the path of early career discovery, or reaching the pointy end of your degree and looking to pack-in real-world experiences before you graduate – Career Accelerator is the go-to for each and every UNSW Business School student.   

In this session, you will find out more about:  

DIGITAL CERTIFICATIONS 
INTERNSHIPS in Australia   
GLOBAL experiences   
MENTORING programs with industry and alumni   
BUSINESS PROJECTS, experiences, skill-up sessions, industry workshops… and more!   

No matter what stage you’re at in your degree, there’s something for everyone. The question is – where to start? The answer: with Career Accelerator!
[CARD]
Read more
[CARD]
Ready, Set, Connect!
Ready, Set, Connect!

3:00 PM - 5:00 PM
Lost for words? Freaked out by ‘networking’?
You’re not alone - but we’ve got you.

In this interactive 2-hour workshop, you’ll learn the why and how of effective networking, craft your elevator pitch, and build the confidence to talk about your skills and strengths with impact.

Start by practicing with your peers in a fun, low-pressure setting, then put your skills into action as you connect with industry professionals who’ll share their insights and top takeaways.

Walk in curious — walk out confident!
